## Graph info
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #38B44A;"}
**Should I use this graph?**
:::

<br>

```{r}
#| label: full_code_display
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| out-height: '60%'
#| out-width: '60%'
#| fig-align: right
library(palmerpenguins) 
library(ggplot2)
penguins_ovrlp <- filter(penguins,
                      !is.na(species) & 
                            island == "Dream")
labs_bar_ovrlp <- labs(
  title = "Adult foraging penguins",
  subtitle = "Penguins on Dream island",
  x = "Flipper length (millimeters)",
  y = "Count",
  fill = "Species")
ggp2_bar_ovrlp <- ggplot(data = penguins_ovrlp,
          aes(x = flipper_length_mm, fill = species)) +
                geom_bar() 
ggp2_bar_ovrlp + 
  labs_bar_ovrlp
```

If we'd like to use two set of overlapping bars to display numerical values for different categorical variable levels, we can use the `fill` argument in `geom_bar()` or `geom_col()`

This results in bars differentiated by color and ‘stacked’ on top of each other.

## Side-to-side bar graphs

`geom_bar()` has additional options for arranging overlapping bars. We can set the `position` argument to `"dodge"` or `"dodge2`, depending on how we'd like the data displayed. 


:::: {.panel-tabset}

### Data

::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #1e83c8;"}
**DATA:**
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
We'll be using the `penguins_dodge` dataset (with missing values removed from `species` and `sex`, and limited to `"Dream"` island)
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r}
#| label: data_code_bar_penguins_dodge
#| eval: true
#| echo: true
penguins_dodge <- filter(penguins,
                      !is.na(species) & 
                        !is.na(sex) &
                            island == "Dream")
glimpse(penguins_dodge)
```
:::


### `dodge`

::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #1e83c8;"}
**`dodge`:**
:::

::: {.column-margin}

- *`position = "dodge"` preserves the vertical position of a geom while adjusting the horizontal position*

- *requires the grouping variable to be be specified in the global or `⁠geom_`⁠ layer*

:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}

Create labels

Map `species` to the `x` and `island` to `group` and `fill` 

Inside the `geom_bar()` function, set `position` to `"dodge"`

:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r}
#| label: code_graph_dodge
#| eval: true
#| echo: true 
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| column: page-inset-right
#| layout-nrow: 1
labs_bar_dodge <- labs(
  title = "Adult foraging penguins",
  subtitle = "Penguins on Dream island",
  x = "Sex",
  y = "Count",
  fill = "Species",
  caption = "position = 'dodge'")
ggp2_bar_dodge <- ggplot(data = penguins_dodge,
                    aes(x = sex, 
                        group = species, 
                        fill = species)) +
                    geom_bar(
                        position = "dodge")
ggp2_bar_dodge +
  labs_bar_dodge
```
:::

### `dodge2`

::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #1e83c8;"}
**`dodge2`:**
:::

::: {.column-margin}

- *works without a grouping variable in a layer*

- *works with bars and rectangles*  

- *useful for arranging graphs with variable widths.*

:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}

Create labels

Map `species` to `x` and `island` to `fill`

Inside `geom_bar()`, set `position` to `"dodge2"`

:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r}
#| label: create_graph_dodge2
#| eval: true
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| column: page-inset-right
#| layout-nrow: 1
labs_bar_dodge2 <- labs(
  title = "Adult foraging penguins",
  subtitle = "Penguins on Dream island",
  x = "Sex",
  y = "Count",
  fill = "Species",
  caption = "position = 'dodge2'")
ggp2_bar_dodge2 <- ggplot(data = penguins_dodge,
                    aes(x = sex, 
                        fill = species)) +
                    geom_bar(
                        position = "dodge2")
ggp2_bar_dodge2 +
  labs_bar_dodge2
```
:::
